summary: This is a sealed motion filed by the United States in the case of Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 vs. United States, seeking dismissal of the petitioners' Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) petition for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The government argues the petitioners lack standing and their claims are not constitutionally ripe, focusing on their request to invalidate the non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida. This is a sealed motion filed by the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, seeking to dismiss the petitioners' (Jane Doe #1 and #2) claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The motion argues that the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein does not preclude federal prosecution in other districts and that the victims' claims regarding their right to confer with prosecutors are not yet ripe for judicial review. The filing includes a related sealed court order authorizing limited disclosure of grand jury information to the petitioners' attorneys.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure who entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, pleading guilty to state charges and serving an 18-month sentence.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking to enforce rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, alleging denial of consultation regarding the disposition of charges against Epstein.

persons.name: Jane Doe #2
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking to enforce rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, who declined an invitation to meet with the United States Attorney.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: The United States Attorney who authorized the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, referenced as the signatory authority for the deferral of prosecution.

persons.name: Wilfredo A. Ferrer
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who respectfully submitted the motion to dismiss on behalf of the government.

persons.name: Dexter A. Lee
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney in Miami, Florida, listed as an attorney for the respondent (United States).

persons.name: Eduardo I. Sanchez
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney in Miami, Florida, listed as an attorney for the respondent (United States).

persons.name: A. Marie Villafana
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney in West Palm Beach, Florida, listed as an attorney for the respondent (United States).

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, with a law office in Hollywood, Florida.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassell
persons.context: Attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, affiliated with the S.J. Quinney College of Law at the University of Utah.

persons.name: Donald M. Middlebrooks
persons.context: The judge who signed the sealed order granting the government's motion for limited disclosure of grand jury matter.

connections.description: Jane Doe #1 is a petitioner alleging Epstein committed federal sex offenses against her as a minor.
Jane Doe #2 is a petitioner alleging Epstein committed federal sex offenses against her as a minor.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, authorized the non-prosecution agreement that deferred federal prosecution of Epstein in favor of state prosecution.
Edwards is listed as an attorney representing Jane Doe #1 (and Jane Doe #2) in the civil case against the United States.
Cassell is listed as an attorney representing Jane Doe #1 (and Jane Doe #2) in the civil case against the United States.

events.title: Hearing on CVRA Petition
events.description: A court hearing where petitioners acknowledged Epstein's reliance on the non-prosecution agreement led to his state guilty plea and incarceration, and where prosecutors stated they would confer with the victims.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney
events.description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, with prosecutors, personally conferred with Jane Doe #1 and petitioners' counsel about desires to prosecute Epstein on federal charges.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a non-prosecution agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution, contingent on Epstein meeting certain conditions.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea and Incarceration
events.description: As induced by the non-prosecution agreement, Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state criminal charges and served an 18-month sentence of state incarceration.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, which is the central subject of the legal dispute. The government argues it does not bar prosecution in other districts.

events.title: Hearing Transcript Reference
events.description: A hearing was held where petitioners' counsel acknowledged the best relief they could hope for was the right to confer with government attorneys about charges against Epstein.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Dismiss and Sealed Order
events.description: The United States filed this sealed motion to dismiss the petitioners' claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. On the same date, Judge Middlebrooks issued a sealed order granting the government's motion for limited disclosure of grand jury information to the petitioners' attorneys.

keyFacts: The U.S. government argues the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over the CVRA petition because the petitioners (Jane Doe #1 and #2) lack Article III standing and their claims are not constitutionally ripe.

The petitioners seek to invalidate the non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to enable consultation about potential federal charges.

The government contends that even if the non-prosecution agreement were set aside, due process requires the U.S. to adhere to its terms because Epstein has fulfilled his obligations (pleading guilty and serving state time).

The non-prosecution agreement did not bar federal prosecution outright; it deferred prosecution in the Southern District of Florida in favor of state prosecution, provided Epstein met conditions, and charges could potentially be brought in other districts (e.g., SDNY, New Jersey).

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida has been recused from the Epstein matter, with responsibility reassigned to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Middle District of Florida.

The U.S. government argues the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein does not prevent federal prosecution in districts other than the Southern District of Florida, citing the U.S. Attorney's Manual which states one district cannot bind another without written approval.

The motion contends the petitioners' (victims') claims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) are not ripe for review because they have not been denied the opportunity to confer with prosecutors about potential future charges against Epstein in other districts.

A sealed court order from November 7, 2011, authorized the limited disclosure of grand jury information from two federal grand juries (05-02 and 07-103) to the attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and #2 for use in their sealed civil case filings.
The document reveals ongoing legal efforts by victims (Jane Doe #1 and #2) to challenge the NPA and assert their rights, with representation from attorneys Brad Edwards and Paul G. Cassell.
